Stem: Diagram shows two parent horses and their foal. Which statements identify traits the foal most likely inherited from its parents?
Image/Diagram Description: Image of two parent horses and foal showing different coat patterns (393x380).
Choices: A) a white tail from its mother, B) a solid body pattern from both parents, C) a spotted body pattern from its father, D) white hair on its face from both parents
Scenario Justification: Visual data showing parent and offspring traits. Students must analyze visual evidence to determine inheritance.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — students compare parent and offspring traits from visual evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of inheritance by matching offspring traits to parent traits using visual data.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (offspring traits match parent patterns).
Key Recommendation: Good visual. Elevate by providing trait data for multiple offspring and asking students to identify inheritance patterns.

Stem: Jacob investigated magnet strength using magnetic train cars. He tried different combinations as shown in the table. Which statement best explains the pattern?
Image/Diagram Description: Data table showing magnet combinations and results (425x376).
Choices: A) Two strong magnets have strong attractive force when same poles face each other, B) Two strong magnets push away with great force when same poles face each other, C) Two weak magnets push away with great force when same poles face each other, D) One strong and one weak magnet have strong attractive force when same poles face each other
Scenario Justification: Experimental scenario with real data table showing magnet interactions. Students must identify the pattern.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — students must read experimental data and identify the pattern explaining the observations.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of magnetic forces to interpret experimental data. Goes beyond simple recall.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (identifying the pattern in magnet behavior from data).
Key Recommendation: Strong data-driven question. Students analyze experimental data to identify patterns in magnet behavior.

Stem: You push on an empty box from the left and your friend pushes from the right. If your friend has about the same amount of strength as you what will happen to the box?
Choices: A) It will move left, B) It will move right, C) It will not move much
Scenario Justification: Basic scenario of balanced forces. Familiar context.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — predicting outcome of balanced forces.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of balanced forces. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (equal forces cause no movement).
Key Recommendation: Add force measurements and data table. Ask students to predict outcomes for different force combinations.

Stem: An elephant pushes a box from the left and a mouse pushes it from the right. What will happen to the box?
Choices: A) The elephant's strength will move it towards the mouse, B) The mouse's strength will move it towards the elephant, C) The box will not move
Scenario Justification: Simple unbalanced forces scenario. Requires reasoning about relative force magnitudes.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — predicting outcome of unbalanced forces.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of unbalanced forces. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (greater force determines direction).
Key Recommendation: Provide force data for different animal pairs and ask students to predict and explain outcomes.

Stem: What would happen if you set a magnet on your desk and slowly move another magnet toward it?
Choices: A) The magnets will certainly repel causing the desk magnet to move away, B) The desk magnet will certainly jump up to the other magnet because it is attracted, C) The magnets will either repel or attract each other, D) Nothing will happen
Scenario Justification: Basic thought experiment with magnets. Requires reasoning about possible outcomes.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — considering multiple possible outcomes depending on orientation.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that magnet interactions depend on pole orientation. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (pole orientation determines interaction type).
Key Recommendation: Add experimental data showing different orientations and outcomes. Ask students to identify the pattern.

Stem: Which of the following is an example of how traits can sometimes be influenced by the environment?
Choices: A) A dog has brown spots on its fur, B) A sunflower in shade still grows but is not very tall, C) A mommy bird gets worms for her babies, D) A student has same color eyes as her mom
Scenario Justification: Examples presented but no rich scenario. Students identify environmental influence on traits.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice engagement. Identifying an example from a list.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that environment can influence trait expression.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (shade → reduced growth).
Key Recommendation: Provide data comparing sunflower heights in different light conditions and ask students to explain the pattern.

Stem: True or False: Children always show all of their parents traits.
Choices: A) True, B) False
Scenario Justification: No scenario. True/false format tests single fact.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Binary recall.
DCI Justification: Tests basic understanding that not all parent traits appear in offspring. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Replace with evidence showing parent and offspring trait data across multiple families. Ask students to explain patterns.

Stem: Which of the following statements is true about life cycles?
Choices: A) Life cycle of every living thing lasts many years, B) Life cycle includes hatching growing and dying, C) Life cycle includes birth growth reproduction death
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall of life cycle stages.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests memorization of life cycle stages. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Show life cycle data for different organisms and ask students to compare patterns.

Stem: Which of the following is true about hair color inheritance?
Choices: A) If mom has black hair and dad has blond hair the child will always have black hair, B) The child could have black hair blond hair or a variation such as brown, C) The child will always have blond hair
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Asks about inheritance variation as isolated fact.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that offspring traits can vary from parents. Recall level with some reasoning.
Key Recommendation: Provide family trait data across generations and ask students to identify inheritance patterns.

Stem: Scientists record patterns of weather across different times and areas so that they can make...
Choices: A) climate, B) weather forecasts, C) adjustments to the weather, D) weather machines
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Fill-in-the-blank style recall.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Vocabulary recall.
DCI Justification: Tests purpose of weather data collection. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Provide weather data and ask students to use it to make predictions.

Stem: An area's typical weather conditions and the extent to which those conditions vary over a period of time is known as...
Choices: A) weather, B) climate, C) weather hazard, D) a forecast
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Definition recall.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Vocabulary recall.
DCI Justification: Tests climate definition. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Provide temperature/precipitation data over different time scales and ask students which describes weather vs. climate.

Stem: A winter season in a particular area having mostly snow and rain and cold temperatures is an example of...
Choices: A) summer typical weather for the desert, B) tropical climate zone, C) a seasonal weather pattern, D) forecasting weather
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario of seasonal conditions. Students must classify the description.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Classification task.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that seasonal conditions form patterns. Application level.
Key Recommendation: Provide multi-year seasonal data and ask students to identify and describe the patterns.

Stem: Variations in traits between individuals in a population...
Choices: A) may provide an advantage for survival, B) do not happen, C) will always cause the destruction of the population
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Asks about trait variation as isolated concept.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that trait variation can be advantageous. Recall level.
Key Recommendation: Only 3 choices. Provide data on trait variation and survival rates to make evidence-based.

Stem: An example of a variation in traits that benefits an organism and helps it to survive is...
Choices: A) a plant with spikey thorns that prevent animals from eating it, B) cutting your hair so it is a different length and style, C) a dog that learns to do a trick, D) a plant that needs a lot of water
Scenario Justification: Lists examples without context. Students identify the correct one.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Identifying an example.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of beneficial trait variation. Identification level.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on plant survival rates with/without thorns in environments with herbivores.

Stem: In a hot dry desert habitat an organism will be more likely to survive if...
Choices: A) it has a trait that helps it conserve water, B) it has a trait that helps it stay warm, C) it has a trait that helps it live in water, D) it has a trait that helps it find food in the snow
Scenario Justification: Desert habitat context but no specific organism or data.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall of adaptation concept.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of environment-adaptation match. Application level.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on organism survival rates with different traits in desert conditions.

Stem: The parts of a habitat...
Choices: A) are all doing the same exact thing, B) form systems in which the parts depend on each other, C) can easily be replaced by another part, D) have no real interaction
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Asks about habitat parts as isolated concept.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of ecosystem interdependence. Recall level.
CCC Justification: Engages Systems and System Models implicitly but not required.
Key Recommendation: Provide food web data and ask students to predict what happens if one component changes.

Stem: Which of these is a behavior that a person learns rather than inherits?
Choices: A) Swallowing a sweet liquid, B) Having a pleasant dream, C) Digesting a chocolate-covered strawberry, D) Identifying the scent of a rose
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Asks students to distinguish learned vs. inherited behaviors.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Classification task at recall level.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of learned vs. inherited behaviors. Some reasoning required to evaluate each option.
Key Recommendation: Provide observation data of identical twins raised in different environments and ask students to identify learned vs. inherited traits.

Stem: If you drop an object off a roof and it falls downward this is because of...
Choices: A) the Earth's gravitational pull, B) static electricity, C) balanced forces, D) magnetic energy
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall of gravity concept.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests basic knowledge of gravity. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Provide data comparing falling objects (different masses, same height) and ask about the pattern.

Stem: Students made a chart classifying animal behaviors. Which animal behavior is NOT correctly classified?
Image/Diagram Description: Chart showing animal behaviors classified as learned or inherited (798x206).
Choices: A) Bear looking for food in a trash can, B) Owl being active at night, C) Dog coming when its name is called, D) Squirrel getting seeds from a bird feeder
Scenario Justification: Uses a data chart showing behavior classifications. Students must evaluate the chart for errors.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — students evaluate a classification chart for accuracy.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of learned vs. inherited behaviors using a data display.
Key Recommendation: Good use of data display. Elevate by providing more behaviors and asking students to classify them with explanations.

Stem: If you have a magnet hovering slightly above a metal paper clip what causes the paper clip to jump up and attach to the magnet?
Choices: A) a magnetic field, B) an electrical field, C) gravity, D) friction
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario of magnet-paperclip interaction.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Identification task.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of magnetic fields. Recall with minor application.
Key Recommendation: Provide experimental data on distance vs. pickup success and ask students to analyze the pattern.

Stem: What causes hair to stand up when you rub a balloon on it?
Choices: A) a magnetic field, B) gravity, C) static electricity, D) friction
Scenario Justification: Common phenomenon but asked as recall.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall of cause.
DCI Justification: Tests basic knowledge of static electricity. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Provide investigation data on different materials rubbed together and resulting charge effects. Ask for pattern analysis.

Stem: Some bats live together in caves. A bat that cannot find food gets food from another bat when it returns to the cave. How does living in a group help a bat survive?
Choices: A) A bat living in a group needs less space in a cave, B) A bat living in a group can get food from other bats, C) A bat living in a group doesn't hunt for food, D) A bat living in a group can find better caves for shelter
Scenario Justification: Rich scenario describing specific group behavior with observable phenomenon (food sharing among bats).
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — students connect the described behavior to a survival advantage.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of group behavior benefits using specific animal example.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (food sharing → survival of individuals who didn't find food).
Key Recommendation: Good scenario. Add data on bat survival rates in different group sizes to make more evidence-based.

Stem: Lions live together in prides. The lionesses do the hunting. The pride depends on the lionesses for...
Choices: A) air, B) water, C) a place to sleep, D) food
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario about lion pride behavior. Simple inference.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Direct inference from the text.
DCI Justification: Tests basic understanding of group roles. Application level.
Key Recommendation: Provide observation data on pride activities and ask students to analyze the division of labor and explain how it benefits survival.

Stem: Which of the following is true about magnet distance and force?
Choices: A) The closer a magnet is to another magnet the stronger the magnetic force, B) The closer the weaker the force, C) Distance does not change force, D) There's no magnetic force between two magnets
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall of distance-force relationship.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of magnetic force-distance relationship. Recall level.
Key Recommendation: Provide experimental data with force measurements at different distances. Ask students to identify the pattern.

Stem: The fur of a fox living in the North changes color from brown to white in winter. What is the main reason for this change?
Choices: A) The fox likes white fur better, B) White fur is warmer in the sun, C) White fur makes it harder for predators to see the fox, D) The fox eats different foods in winter that make its fur change
Scenario Justification: Seasonal adaptation scenario. Students must reason about camouflage advantage.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — connecting seasonal color change to survival advantage.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of camouflage as survival adaptation. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (white fur in snow → harder to see → survival benefit).
Key Recommendation: Provide predation rate data for foxes in summer vs. winter coat colors and ask students to analyze.

Stem: Which of these statements are true about the force of gravity?
Choices: A) Gravity can make an object's upward motion faster, B) On Earth gravity pulls objects toward the center of the Earth, C) Gravity can cause an object's downward motion to decrease, D) Gravity can push objects upward
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall of gravity facts.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests basic gravity knowledge. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Provide data from drop experiments and ask students to analyze patterns.

Stem: Which of these is NOT a stage in the life cycle of a mammal?
Choices: A) birth, B) larva, C) adolescent, D) adult
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Recall of mammal life cycle stages.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests knowledge of mammal vs. insect life cycle stages. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Show unfamiliar organism life cycle data and ask students to classify which type of life cycle it represents.

Stem: The ability of magnets to attract and repel can be very useful for inventors. Which problem could be solved by a magnet?
Choices: A) a cupboard door that keeps falling open, B) a backpack that is too heavy, C) a toaster that doesn't work
Scenario Justification: Engineering application context. Students must connect magnet properties to a practical problem.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' at basic level — identifying which problem could be solved with magnets.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of magnetic properties and their practical applications.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (magnet attraction → door latch function).
Key Recommendation: Only 3 choices. Provide multiple engineering problems with constraints and ask students to design a magnet-based solution.

Stem: Some plants leave imprints of their leaves in sediment that later hardens into rock. What does this type of fossil tell us about the plant?
Choices: A) It tells us what the plant ate, B) It tells us what the plant looked like, C) It tells us how the plant moved, D) It tells us how old the plant is
Scenario Justification: Brief fossil formation scenario. Students must reason about what information leaf imprints provide.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — reasoning about evidence from fossils.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of what fossils can tell us. Application level.
Key Recommendation: Provide actual fossil images and ask students to make inferences about the ancient organism and its environment.

Stem: Students hang magnets at different heights above a tray of tacks. The magnets attract different numbers of tacks as shown in the diagram. What can the students conclude?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing magnets at different heights picking up different numbers of tacks (302x181).
Choices: A) Magnet 1 and 3 are strongest because closest to tacks, B) Magnet 2 and 3 are strongest because they can reach more tacks in the middle, C) Magnet 3 and 4 are strongest because they pick up the greatest number of tacks, D) Magnet 2 and 4 are strongest because they pick up tacks from a greater distance
Scenario Justification: Rich experimental scenario with visual data showing magnets at different heights picking up tacks. Students must analyze the data to identify which magnets are strongest.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — students must interpret experimental data to draw conclusions about magnet strength vs. distance.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of magnetic force-distance relationship to experimental data. Deep reasoning about what 'strength' means in context.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (stronger magnets → attract from further distance) and Patterns (pattern in distance vs. pickup).
Key Recommendation: Excellent data-driven question. Students analyze experimental evidence to draw conclusions about magnet strength.

Stem: During fall a male brook trout's belly becomes bright orange. Males with bright-orange bellies attract more females than pale-orange males. How does the orange-belly trait most likely help brook trout?
Choices: A) It helps the fish grow in size, B) It helps the fish produce offspring, C) It helps the fish control their behavior, D) It helps the fish survive temperature changes
Scenario Justification: Rich scenario with real-world observation data about trait variation and reproductive advantage in brook trout.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — connecting trait variation to reproductive success using observed evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that traits can provide reproductive advantages beyond just survival. Goes beyond basic adaptation recall.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (bright color → attract mates → more offspring) and Patterns (correlation between color brightness and mate attraction).
Key Recommendation: Good scenario with real data. Elevate by providing mate selection data across multiple generations and asking about trait frequency changes.

Stem: A green tree frog lives in a forest. How does the frog's green color help it to survive?
Choices: A) By helping the frog find other frogs, B) By keeping the frog cool, C) By making the frog hard to see when sitting on leaves, D) By allowing the frog to make its own food
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario of frog camouflage. Basic application.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Recall of camouflage function.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of camouflage as survival adaptation.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on predation rates for frogs of different colors in different environments.
